title: The Present Tense of Regular Verbs, Irregular Verbs, and Verbs with Speling Changes

lessons.text: Regular Verbs in the Present Tense

text: To form the present tense, drop the -ar, -er, or -ir from the root (or radical) of the inﬁnitive, and add the ending that corresponds to the subject.
The following verbs can be used as models for all regular verbs in the present tense.
The first-person singular yo has the same ending in all three conjugations.
In the -er and -ir verb categories all three third-person singular forms have the same endings.
Subject pronouns are usually omitted in Spanish unless they are needed for clarification or emphasis.

text: -to describe an action happening now. Often, it is translated with the -ing form in English:
examples: Ahora, veo a Anna (Now I see Anna)
Louis llega a la puerta (Louis is arriving at the gate)

text: -to express actions that take place regularly:
examples: Normalmente, compro las frutas en el supermercado (Usually I buyfruit at the supermarket)

text: -to describe events that will take place in the near future:
examples: Mañana discuto el plan con ustedes en la reunion (Tomorrow I will discuss the plan at the meeting)
Este verano, viajo a Alemania (This summer I am traveling to Germany)

text: -to ask questions, especially regarding permission, opinion, or preference:
examples: ¿Bebes café o tê? (Do you drink coffee or tea?)
¿Abro la puerta? (Shall I open the door?)
¿Compramos la casa? (Shall we buy the house?)

text: Keep in mind the auxiliary verb do in English is not translated. In Spanish, an auxiliary verb is not needed to ask a question.

lessons.text: Other uses of the present tense

text: -to tell facts considered unquestionable or universal truths:
examples: Cinco mas quince son veinte (Five plus fifteen is twenty.)

text: -to describe a past event, making it more vivid (historial present:
examples: En 1969 el primer hombre llega a la luna (The first man gets to the moon in 1969.)

text: -to express future actions that are part of a schedule or itinerary:
examples: El tren sale a las ocho (The train leaves at eight.)

text: to express hypothetical actions introduced by si.
examples: Si llega el tren, salimos (If the train arrives, we leave.)

text: to refer to possible consequences from an action that took place in the past with casi (almost) and por poco (nearly)
examples: Sacé la pistola y casi me mata (He pulled out his gun and almost killed me.)

lessons.text: Irregular Verbs in the Present Tense

text: Many Spanish verbs do not follow the patterns of the regular verbs you have just studied.
Instead, they change the root (or radical) of the verb, the conjugation endings, or both.
Because they follow different patterns, they are considered irregular verbs.
Since irregular verbs are so commonly used, a good strategy to identify and learn them is to focus on similarities, grouping them into patterns.

lessons.text: Other Frequently Used Verbs with Irregular Forms in the Present Tense

text: Study the conjugation of the following verbs
They have irregular forms in the present tense:
Note that haber is also irregular.
One meaning of haber is to have
However, in the present as well as in other tenses, haber is more frequently used as an impersonal verb in the third-person singular form.
The present tense form is hay. It means there is and there are.
examples: Hay tres sillas en la sala (There are three chairs in the living room.)
Hay una posibilidad solamente (There is only one possibiility)

text: Compounds of tener have the same irregular forms

lessons.text: Verbs with spelling Changes in the present tense

text: In the present tense, certain verbs have spelling changes.
These are determined by Spanish rules of pronunciation to preserve the sound appearing in the inﬁnitive.
The following groups of verbs have spelling changes before the verb ending -o, in the yo form only.
examples: Verbs ending in -ger or -gir change g to j before the -o ending

examples: Verbs ending in -guir gu to g before the o- ending:

exercises.title: Yo tambien
exercises.instructions: Write the present tense of the yo form of the verb

text: Dar, haber, hacer, and tener have irregular forms in the present.
They appear frequently in idiomatic expressions
Many are formed with a conjugated verb + infinitive, called formas perifrásticas or perífrasis verbales
Note the use of present tense in the examples with dar, haber, hacer, and tener that follow
Dar
examples: dar un abrazo (to hug) => Le da un abrazo a su amigo
dar gritos (to shout) => La multitud de gritos
dar la hora (to strike the hour) => El reloj da la una

text: Haber
examples: hay que + infinitive (to be necessary) => Hay que estudiar para aprendar
haber sol (to be sunny => hay sol por la mañana
haber neblina (to be foggy) => Hay neblina este mañana

exercises.title: Y en tu caso...
questions: Mi reloj da la una y media

text: Hacer
examples: Hacer calor, hace fresco (to be warm, to be cool) => Hace fresco, no hace calor
hacer viento (to be windy) => Hace viento
hacer un viaje (to take a trip) => Lina hace un viaje a las Bahamas
hacer una visita (to pay a visit) => Marcus hace una visita a su abuela
hacer una pregunta (to ask a question) => El profesor hace una pregunta
hacer daño (to harm) => Beber much agua no te hace daño
hacer caso a (to pay attention to) => Los niños no hacen caso al maestro
hacer el papel de (to play the role of) => El actor hace el papel de un policia

text: Tener
examples: tener + que + infinitive (to have to do something) => Tenemos que salir
tener frio (to be cold) => Tengo frio
tener hambre (to be hungry) => ¿Tienes hambre?
tener miedo (to be scared) => No tienen miedo a las serpientes
tener razón (to be right) => Yo tingo razón
tener sed (to be thirsty) => ¿Tienes sed?
tener prisa (to be in a hurry) => Mi esposo tiene prisa
tener culpa (to be to blame) => El sospechoso tiene la culpa de este accidente
tener lugar (to take place) => La reunion tiene lugar los domingos
